speaker_segments.text: Of course, my name is Brittany Rosario.
I work with Wilming as the University Relations and Recruiting Lead.
I've worked in recruiting well over 10 years, super passionate about it.
And I also really enjoy just teaching our young adults, just tips and tricks on what to do as they're stepping into the real world.
Thank you, Brittany, for being here.
All right, Andrew Buffet, Canada went electric.
Not a full-time recruiter, but really do for my company kind of lead our university recruiting efforts.
So hopefully, you know, they will provide some insight today.
Thank you, Andrew, for being here.
Jesse, how about you?
Jesse Prout.
I'm a senior project manager with Chase Building Team.
I'm a graduate of the Dell Web School Construction Program 2014.
Also currently a faculty associate, so I do a little bit of teaching as well.

And similarly, I'm mainly in operations, but I do also do a lot of recruiting, sat in a lot of interviews, do a lot to help mentor students transitioning into the real world and people out of transitioned into the real world.
Yeah, thank you so much for being here.
These three individuals represent three of our biggest donors at the Daliob School of Construction, and we appreciate that.
Keeps the lights on around here.
So, you know, I expect one of your main goals of coming to the Daliob School of Construction and ASU is to get your first job.
And as you'll learn in this class, Daliob requires two internships.
So we anticipate that many of the students watching this may be incoming freshmen, some incoming juniors, but either case in order to graduate with your construction management degree,
you have to have two summer internships.
And so as we require that for your graduation, we want to do everything we can to help you find that job, both the internship and your full-time job.
So with that being said, your resume is an important piece of communication.
an important document to open the doors to companies.
And so our first conversation here is going to be on your resume and in advance of a career fair.
And then our second conversation will be around LinkedIn and how to use LinkedIn, social media to help you also land that right job.
So I think we'll just dig in with the first question about resumes.
And I'll just throw to you, Brittany, to start.
We'll give you the hardest ones.
What would you say are some important sections that a student would want to include in their resume?
I think it's important to have a summary of some technologies you're experienced with.
And sometimes you might know a lot of technologies and don't put all of them as much as you might want to have your skills have 40 or 50 of them.
You want to put the most relatable on top because the way AI works now, especially
turn and burn recruiters and staffing agencies, they'll glance at your resume.
The reality is recruiters will look at your resume for maybe four to five seconds.
That's just the reality.
And you have hundreds if not sometimes thousands of resumes in there, so you want
relatable information that's going to be at a glance on your resume so that that resumes look that and moved on to the next step.
So a lot of these students, just to make sure we're famous, maybe high school graduates, and maybe they've been out ASU for two weeks or a month.
And so a lot of the things that we might see on graduates resumes, they haven't got them yet.
Exactly.
And so that kind of leads to a question around, and I'll just show this one to Andrew.
Can high school activities, high school grade point, if I'm an incoming freshman, is it okay for me to have that on the resume?
And what kinds of things from high school experience could I put on my new ASU resume?
Yeah.
I love that.
I mean, especially for an incoming freshman, right?
Because you got to have something, right?
And your work experience many times won't be applicable, right?
So it's what, did you apply yourself in high school, right?
By evidence of your GPA, did you, by chance, take some college courses in high school, right?
Showing some initiative, right?
Did you, were you a part of, you know, club's organizations, just things, right?
And did you seek out opportunities to
you know, make your place of education better, right?
Like student council, things like that, right?
So yeah, I'd say all about that.
And then, yeah, obviously, as you build through your university career, right?
Some of that stuff might drop off because you'll have more applicable internships and things, but that might include my high school GPA.
I like that idea.
